summary: A visually stunning sequel, but narratively unbalanced and emotionally disappointing
text:
I wanted to love Zootopia 2. I truly did. The first film meant a lot to me, so much that it genuinely influenced my life choices back in 2016 (I even ended up working "for the mouse" for a couple of years afterward). That movie had heart, nuance, and emotional resonance.

This sequel... left me uneasy.

Spoilers below

The biggest disappointment for me was Pawbert being revealed as a villain. I was hoping for at least one redeeming member of the Lynxley family to break the cycle - whether it was Kitty, Cattrick, or heck... even Milton. Instead, the movie portrays every single one of them as corrupt or malicious, which by extension makes the entire species of lynx look that way since they are virtually the only ones we see. That lack of balance really soured the ending for me.

And then there's Judy. She doesn't truly apologizes to Nick after he risks his life to save her. She doesn't reflect on her mistakes or acknowledge the danger she put him in. That scene felt strangely hollow, especially considering how emotionally intelligent the first film was.

For the first time, I genuinely found it hard to connect with Judy.

To be clear: Zootopia 2 is not a horrible movie. There were so funny moments. It is gorgeous and full of energy. But its narrative choices lacked the nuance and emotional maturity that made the original so impactful.

summary: An excellent sequel that nearly matches the magic of the original.
text:
Zootopia 2 is an excellent follow-up that manages to honor the spirit of the original while confidently carving out its own identity. Even without the novelty that made the first film such a standout, this sequel demonstrates a strong understanding of what audiences loved most: the vibrant world, the sharp comedic timing, and, above all, the partnership between Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde. Their dynamic once again anchors the story, offering a satisfying mix of charm, banter, and genuine emotional resonance.

The sequel broadens the scope of the city and introduces new environments and characters that feel consistent with the world's established tone. Rather than feeling like gimmicks, these additions help refresh the setting and provide new angles for humor and character-driven moments. The writing maintains a balance between lighthearted fun and meaningful themes, echoing the first film's strength in blending entertainment with commentary. While the thematic exploration may not cut as deeply as the original's allegories, the film still engages with thoughtful ideas in a way that feels accessible and sincere.

Visually, the movie remains impressive, with playful details, expressive animation, and lively crowd scenes that make Zootopia feel more alive than ever. The pacing occasionally loosens in the midsection, and a few story beats feel slightly less tight than the first film's mystery-driven structure, but these are small drawbacks in an otherwise confident sequel.

Overall, Zootopia 2 is a highly enjoyable and skillfully executed continuation that may not be quite as groundbreaking, but undeniably excellent and worthy of being one of Disney's best movies (or sequel films) in years.

summary: A Sequel Worth the Nine-Year Wait
text:
Sometimes a movie grows up with you. The first Zootopia was one of those for me. I watched it with my sister years ago, and by the time the credits rolled, we were both wishing with all our hearts for a sequel. It became one of those comfort films that stayed with me-funny, warm, and unexpectedly meaningful.

And now, after nine long years, we finally have the sequel we waited for. I didn't expect much, especially after the trailers. Honestly, I watched it almost bracing myself for disappointment. But what I got instead... was something that felt like a gift. A reminder of why I fell in love with the first movie in the first place.

The animation is once again fantastic. The city is as vibrant and imaginative as ever, and exploring more of its districts was such a treat. The humor landed perfectly-the animal puns, the movie references, the quick visual gags. I was laughing far more than I expected.

The plot surprised me most. It felt stronger and even darker than the first movie, in the best way. I want the Zootopia franchise to keep exploring these deeper themes-kids' movies can and should teach something meaningful while entertaining us. And it was twisty! Sure, some people guessed the villain early (I did too), but somewhere along the way I actually started to trust them. And then-BOOM. A full Hans-level betrayal. My jaw actually dropped. I hoped they'd deliver a twist like the first film, and I'm so glad they did.

The characters were a joy. Judy and Nick are unstoppable, clever, and more dynamic than ever. The new characters-Gary, Nibbles, the Horse Mayor-brought humor, comfort, and absolute cuteness. Seeing Mr. Big's granddaughter, Gazelle's choreography, Flash's last moment support, Bellwether's little escape attempt... all of it was fun and wholesome.

But my favorite part? Judy and Nick's depth. They have several genuinely emotional moments together. I'm not even a hardcore shipper (just a casual one), but I was screaming, crying, bawling for them. Judy did get a bit annoying at times, but her heart is as fierce as ever. Meanwhile, Nick had my love from the first second-wiser, calmer, and honestly the perfect partner and cop. Their bond, whatever you want to call it, healed my inner child. It was exactly what I needed.

The message of the film is beautifully done and extremely relevant. The monologues feel sincere and grounded. The film talks about understanding one another, working through differences, and learning to express ourselves. And yes, the classic "don't judge a book by its cover" theme still hits home. I will forever pray that animated films keep delivering messages as well as this.

Final take: I watched it with zero expectations and finished it loving it even more than the first. Sequels like this-and Inside Out 2-make me believe in that old Disney-Pixar magic again. My heartfelt thanks to the entire team for creating a sequel that made me feel like a child all over again. You brought back a piece of magic I thought I'd lost.

I was very nervous going into this film and having seen it twice now, to say I'm disappointed would be an understatement. I'm a forever lover of animation and a major fan of the first "Zootopia" film which I've rewatched over 2 dozen times. This sequel is an underwhelming, confusing, and poorly written follow up to the legacy of the original. Just because it wasn't COMPLETELY unbearable to watch does not make it good and I refuse to lower my standards in light of Disney's recent struggles. How can this be the standard Disney has come to? Why is this weak quality of writing what kids of today are forced to grow up with?

While the first film features Judy actively searching for clues, using her detective skills and logic to solve the case, this movie force feeds Judy (and all the other characters for that matter) every clue and coincidence they could ever need.

Nick and Judy happened to get access to a vehicle to chase down a criminal they were pursuing. Judy happened to see a snake slither out of the van she overtook because the driver happened to fall unconscious at the wheel. Judy happened to turn on her TV at the perfect time to see the same catering van. Nick happened to drop his earbud in the perfect location to see shed skin. Judy happened to find a highly knowledgeable beaver via her podcast that also happened to have connections to Mr. Big's daughter. Gary happened to lose his fanny pack and it happened to be washed out with Nick and Judy. Judy happened to match a flower that a mountain goat happened to spit out to a set of matches. Judy happened to be saved from falling because Pawsley was there. A guard happened to leave a mop near Nibbles. Flash happened to drive in front of Judy as she was about to be shot. I could go on and on but you get the idea. None of the characters here really struggled at any point in the movie. I understand it's a cartoon but cartoons also need to be believable. There are no real hurdles for the characters to grow from or overcome, it all reads as "I was in the right place at the right time".

One of this film's other major faults is that it features many, many illogical scenes, especially near the end of the story.

The whole plot has the characters follow the shedding skin of a snake? Why is this snake constantly molting? Does it need medical attention? Later on, why would the mountain goats disclose to complete strangers that there was a snake hideout in their honeymoon lodge? Near the end, this movie tries to convince you that a snake (which is a cold blooded reptile that cannot generate its own body heat by the way) can survive subzero temperatures if a scarf is partially wrapped around its torso. It tries to convince you that a limping lynx that fell from a large height is capable of running faster than a snowplow as it bulldozes through the bushy walls of a labyrinth. It also tries to convince you that a city that has been buried under snow for over 100 years not only has no mold, no still air, and no visible structural damage aside for faint cracks but also has functioning lights that can all be switched on via turning a single light bulb (suggesting the whole town has a single series circuit). But the most egregious example of their failure was to feature modern crayons and coloured markers in a century old city. This movie also established that tortoises are incredibly slow yet in the flashback we see the maid was able to get a PIECE OF PAPER out of a fireplace before it ignited.

The new characters were flat and greatly underdeveloped for how much screen time they got, with no real interests or flaws (unless they benefited the plot). Judy and Nick were not shown going to therapy enough to justify the 2 minutes of monologuing at each other while standing perfectly still. The lizard fella was useless and we spent way too much time on him for him not to benefit the plot at all. This movie kept building to points without them ever coming to anything, we jump around the city and get nowhere.

This movie reused nearly every joke from the first movie as if to say "Remember when it was funny the first time we did it? Look how funny it is when we repeat it!" It includes characters from the previous movie but they barely benefited the story. The twist villain was very predictable.

This movie has no strong emotional beats, it rushes through everything, and it shoves its message down everyone's throats. It also takes a very lighthearted tone and uses Nick's traumas as a punchline. It nearly completely removed itself from the relatable realities of city living or Judy's strong identity as a cop.

Nothing in this sequel was established in the first movie.

There is so much I haven't even touched upon in this long winded rambling... just... this is exhausting, this movie really is barely passable.

Much like in "Moana 2" the post credit scene suggests there'll be a 3rd movie, I can only clasp my hands in prayer that it'll be at least slightly better than this one.

Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde are the first rabbit/fox partnership in Zootropolis' police department. Despite their success in the previous movie in foiling a citywide conspiracy which went right to the very top, water buffalo police chief Bogo is determined to keep them at the most junior level. And, guess, what, they discover another conspiracy. But does anyone believe them?

This sequel treads some very similar ground to its predecessor but, for the most part does so well. There are some entertaining new characters (the ZeBros made me chuckle), some great new locations, and some nice life lessons about trust, betrayal, not pre-judging, family etc.

On the not-so-good side, let me list:
Chief Bogo really irritates me. I know it's a kids film, but his character's stubborn insistence in suppressing Hopps' ambition means he's not a very credible boss. That, or he's a sexist/speciesist character who shouldn't be in that job.

The film is packed to the rafters with gags. Unfortunately the pace is so frenetic that many of them fly by so fast that they're gone before you have the chance to register them. An exception to this is the point when they enter a snow covered hedge maze. As the camera lifts up to reveal it, the score delivers the ominous chords familiar from Kubrick's The Shining. And...
A number of the gags, like that one, are clearly pitched at adults, not kids.

A couple of major sequences later in the movie take place in low-light, dim, dingy locations, which fail to make full use of the medium.

It's not a bad film, but it falls short of the first one.

I normally would start this review with my thoughts about the original, but if I'm honest I can't remember what I thought about it, and I've not felt driven to rewatch it since the first viewing at the cinema. With the initial reviews I saw being universally negative, I was pleasantly surprised with how much I did enjoy it.

Just a week after becoming partners, and still bathing in their success saving the city, Judy Hopps (Ginnifer Goodwin) and Nick Wilde (Jason Bateman) are naturally over-confident in their abilities. When they bungle a bust on a smuggling ring, and clash over their varying enthusiasm levels, they begin to question just how suitable a partnership they really are. They investigate the potential return to the city of a snake, a species long since removed from the biosphere and come to learn a dark truth about the origins of Zootropolis.

There perhaps should be no surprise that, despite the relatively quick turnarounds of this and "Moana 2" the film looks excellent. There's so much small detail built into each shot, throwaway gags and moments it's very impressive. There's also a rich vein of homage and parody, the cutdown "Silence of the Lambs" moments is well discussed, but there's an excellent "The Shining" homage too. The performances from the cast are good, even if perhaps nobody strays to far away from the sort of characters they most commonly play, it's a deep bench too, with Michelle Gomez, Mae Martin and Cecila Strong being amongst the calibre of acters to just play one scene cameos.

I thought the story was reasonable, though some of the twists I felt I did see coming. That said I'm not exactly the films target audience.

I'm probably not going to feel the need to watch this one again for the next few years either, but it was enjoyable enough at the time.

summary: A sequel that plays it safe
text:
Ten years after the first movie, bunny Judy Hopps and fox Nick Wilde embark together on a new adventure in the universe of Zootopia, revisiting themes of diversity and inclusion, in a way that even the American right will find non-threatening.

The film starts off well, struggles to move forward in its middle section, and regains some of its energy in the last twenty minutes. Overall, it's a bit of a "nothing sandwich," but a well-constructed one, clearly made with substantial resources.

The end credits note that the film was directed by "the entire team at Disney Animation Studios," and that's exactly the impression it leaves: a movie that's highly commercial and impersonal, executed professionally by a skilled corporate team.

(Mission Impossible Zootopia). As for the endless and arch cultural reference gags...yup, it shows the creators were totally wink wink....so it gives the adults a laugh, but not the kids.

This is not a film that will captivate kids, or a film that they will remember. It is visual and storyline overload. But amazing animation.

summary: Great Family Entertainment - Fun, Fast, Sophomoric
text:
Zootopia II is a well-written, energetic, and often delightful family film-absolutely worth seeing in a theater, where its color, sound, and pacing feel far more immersive than they would on a distracted night at home. When watched with focus, it delivers a mix of clever writing for adults and broad humor for kids, making it a genuinely enjoyable family outing.

But it is not the equal of the original.

The first Zootopia succeeded because it was unique, warm, and careful. Characters were introduced thoughtfully. The emotional beats were earned. The audience grew to love the world and its residents gradually, with intention.

Zootopia II, by contrast, tries to build a complex and sprawling backstory that becomes more confusing than compelling. It introduces new characters at a rapid-fire pace-sometimes so quickly that it feels as though the filmmakers were determined to cram in as many celebrity voices and toy-ready characters as possible. The result is a sequel that occasionally feels like the more chaotic sophomore films of the 1980s-think Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom or Home Alone 2-fun and energetic, but unfocused and not nearly as strong as the original.

Where the Film Works

When the movie slows down-even briefly-the smart writing shines.

There are clever Easter eggs throughout (the "Zoogle" search engine gag, among many others), and these understated jokes and references reward adults without overshadowing the story. At its best, the film uses intelligent plot devices-like recording tech-to ground the action in relatable stakes and emotional reality.

During these quieter, character-focused moments, Zootopia II remembers what made the first film special.

Where It Falters

When it tries to appeal to the youngest kids with nonstop gags, impossible physics, and cartoonish chaos, the film loses its way. The tone occasionally drifts into the worst of 1980s Looney Tunes energy-over-the-top antics that break the film's internal logic and undermine the emotional weight of the story.

The longevity of great animated films comes from relatability-moments of humanity, even in a fantastical world. Zootopia II simply has too many gags and not enough grounding. The overstuffed roster of characters makes it difficult to track relationships or care about new additions.

Final Thoughts

There is a very good movie inside Zootopia II-one that surfaces clearly whenever the filmmakers slow down and let the story breathe. It's smart, often funny, visually rich, and full of potential. But the frenetic pace, character overload, and sequel-itis keep it from achieving the elegance and heart of the original.

I genuinely hope that if a Zootopia III is made, the creators take a cue from the strongest sequels in film history: slow down, focus on character, deepen the humor, and trust the audience enough not to drown them in noise.

Still, for families?

It's quality entertainment, worth the price of a movie ticket-especially if you can catch it in a theater while it's still playing.

summary: An excellent expansion to a fantastic universe.
text:
A colorful, creative universe; a city bursting with life and mystery; charismatic, well-developed characters. These are the main strengths of Jared Bush and Byron Howard's creation. With a fantastic cast, highly imaginative art direction, and sound design crafted with real care and attention, Zootopia stands out as one of the most acclaimed animated projects of recent years, earning over 1 billion dollars at the international box office and winning the 2017 Oscar for Best Animated Feature, along with several other notable awards such as the Golden Globe, Critics Choice Awards, Annie Awards, and more. Because of that, Zootopia 2, its sequel, has always had a pretty high bar to clear if it hoped to match or even surpass the level of its predecessor. Still, the second film in the franchise secures its success by holding onto the aspects that made the first one so iconic, while adding its own creative decisions to the universe and to the characters (both returning and new) in a satisfying way.

Shortly after the events of the first film, Nick and Judy set off on a new adventure to uncover a mystery tied to an old chapter in Zootopia's history. What follows is a series of sequences filled with action, comedy, and charm, without forgetting to make space for character development, reflection, and relationships. New characters are introduced organically into the story and add a lot to how the plot unfolds. The dynamic between Nick and Judy is explored in a deeper and more realistic way, and it's genuinely a treat to watch them connect and understand each other better by the end. The film's theme (or "moral lesson," so to speak) remains quite similar to the first, but there are enough new nuances to justify that. Despite the many strong points, the movie still suffers from rushing through the final act, keeping some important scenes from landing with the weight they deserve; it also shares Disney's recent struggle in creating memorable, well-developed villains with coherent motivations (even in the first movie, the villain was arguably one of the most forgettable characters). Even so, a few standout moments make you want to set those issues aside.

In conclusion, Zootopia 2 is a well-crafted and truly necessary sequel to the first film, expanding its worldbuilding and offering deeper development to its characters. It's an immensely pleasant movie to watch-light without being bland-and it delivers at the very least good entertainment and, at its best, a genuinely unforgettable experience.

Nine years is a long time, but Zootopia 2 delivers.

Judy and Nick are back, and their friendship is the heart of the film. Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman have effortless chemistry, balancing humor and genuine emotion perfectly. The new characters shine too, especially Ke Huy Quan's surprisingly sweet Gary and Andy Samberg's hilarious Pawbert.

The animation is stunning. A chase through the water Tube system alone is worth the ticket price. The mystery keeps you guessing, the action thrills, and Shakira's "Zoo" will be stuck in your head for days.

Zootopia 2 made me feel like a kid again. I loved every minute.

Watching this sequel, I honestly felt like I'd just slipped back into the same world without missing a beat. The continuity was smooth, almost comforting, and I liked how the story carried the themes from the first film without trying to reinvent anything. There was a soft touch of mystery woven into the plot and a surprising bit of grounded realism, even with all the colourful chaos happening around the characters.

I still really enjoy watching Judy and Wilde together. Their chemistry feels natural and warm, and part of me keeps wondering if the two of them will ever just push things to the next level instead of endlessly skirting around it. At the same time, maybe the teasing works because it keeps their dynamic playful. Either way, their relationship remains one of the strongest parts for me.

What impressed me most was how the film simply built on what was already there. It didn't force new ideas just for the sake of novelty; it stayed smart enough to expand the foundation instead of replacing it. But that also led to one of my issues. At certain points it felt almost too similar to what I'd seen before, like the same story framework with fresh decorations. The familiar cartoon chases and kid-friendly zaniness also wore me out a bit. I kept wishing for more of that slightly darker undertone the original balanced so well.

Once the plot settled, I found it pretty predictable, and the ending wrapped up way too neatly for my taste. Once the truth came out and the villains were exposed, the community shifted its attitude toward the reptiles almost instantly. I couldn't shake the feeling that something that deeply rooted would take real time to heal. Watching everyone suddenly embrace unity made the resolution feel rushed, especially after all the build up about fear and prejudice.

Still, I can't deny I had fun. I think I still prefer the first one, maybe because I've rewatched it so many times that it's burned into my memory. Maybe this one just needs another viewing to grow on me. Either way, it's a good film and a genuinely solid sequel that respects what came before it.

summary: I'm shocked it was that good
text:
I am at a loss for words. This was a wonderful surprise to be sure. After an entire year of not so great movies, we finally have a movie that is genuinely good/great. Byron Howard and Jared Bush did a fantastic job with this movie. For a movie that was in development since 2017, which is one year after the original film came out, it really does shows that they had enough time in the oven to craft something amazing. Much like Inside Out 2, Zootopia 2 isn't afraid to expand the story and the universe while also introducing great new characters. Key Huy Quan as Gary De'Snake was by far the best of the newcomers.

You can tell the cast and crew had fun with this movie. The humor is honestly ever funnier than the first. At one point, Nick brings up childhood trauma and Chief Bogo respond with "do you want adult trauma?" But probably the most funniest moment in the movie is when Judy and Nick were looking for the viper and when she thinks Nick found the viper, it's revealed that he found "a vindow viper" me and the rest of my theater laughed a lot during this movie. No matter how dark the movie was, it still had heartfelt moments to go along with it as well as moments that made me gasp or even cry. Nick & Judy fighting over the Carrot Pen as they are climbing to the Honeymoon Lodge was a cute scene at first but then once the Carrot Pen shattered to pieces, it broke my heart and the fact that Judy didn't continue to argue with Nick but just kept moving without saying a word was perfect. I was expecting her to continue the argument with Nick but Disney handled that scene the right way. The ending of this movie was genuinely heartfelt especially when Nick Wilde repaired the Carrot Pen and Judy Hopps recorded him saying "love you partner". It doesn't mean they are a romantic couple, it just means that they are best partners and friends at the moment. Which is good. The only one problem that I have with this film is the villain. I saw it coming from a mile away that Pawbert was going to be the main villain of the movie. But, he is at least a better twist villain than Bellwether, I'll give him that. Judy Hopps has always been my favorite character in these movies but Gary De'Snake is a close second for me. Key Huy Quan brought so much heart to this movie and his role. It's also nice to see Patrick Warburton in this. The new mayor that he plays in this movie is funny and badass. When he kicks the tails of the Lynxleys, it was super satisfying to watch. The character dynamics between Judy & Nick are well fleshed out and it's interesting to see their partnership unfold on screen. And finally, the movie is not as politically heavy as the first film which is a welcome addition because I come for a good fun movie than a lecture. Listen, you should go see this movie. It is well worth watching even if you're just about done with Disney. 9.5/10.

summary: Zootopia is back to the top of the food chain
text:
Let's rip this band-aid off right now. Zootopia 2 is not a masterpiece. It doesn't surpass the original, nor is it even as good. It is a definitive step down. That said, it is still an immensely enjoyable experience, and leagues better than the other recent output by Disney.

We might as well start with the paw-sitives. Michael Giaccino has returned to compose the soundtrack for this film, and as always, brings his A-game. Giaccino perfectly encapsulated the feel of this world, and created a sound I honestly would listen to on its own.

The visuals are another incredible step up from the original. The first one looked amazing, but the new engine Disney used to render this picture makes the colors pop even more. The motion is fluid and mesmerizing, and each character has their personality shine through their animations. From Judy's floppy ears, to Gary's tail twisting to form a thumb, each character is fully realized by the incredibly talented team.

The humor, for me at least, is easily on par with the first one. From the complex environmental humor to the simple name replacement of popular brands. Almost all of the jokes land for all audiences. They even threw in an unexpected threesome joke halfway through the film. The group I went with was very divided on that one. Some felt it went too far and was inappropriate for kids, but for me, it was a welcome return to the way family films used to be. Kids wouldn't understand that joke, and it provides a reason to rewatch it as an adult, unlike most family films, which are fully uninteresting to adults.

MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD

The story is one of my few major criticisms of this film. Disney has once again fallen into the trap of, what I have dubbed the "Incredibles 2 Syndrome." That being retreading the same plotline from the first. Judy and Nick once again have to learn how to work together, a group of animals is once again being oppressed by someone in order to retail power, and once again, Judy must prove herself to the ZPD and herself that she is a capable cop. These redundancies made me groan multiple times in annoyance.

As upset as I am about this retread, it's not all doom and gloom. We once again have another twist villain, but this one is actually handled significantly better. Bellwether was revealed far too close to the end, with next to no foreshadowing. This new antagonist has a real motivation beyond simple power, and is foreshadowed well enough for a family film. To make it even better, this antagonist isn't the only one. We also have truly hateable villains who are revealed to be villains almost immediately.

While I could point out my other issues with this film, in truth, they aren't huge deals. And who really wants to read the nitpicky ramblings of a random cinephile? There are a few small plotholes, dumb decisions, and truly asinine writing decisions that take up a sizable chunk of the film, but ultimately don't drag the score down too much. If you're looking for a fun film to watch with your family, this will definitely satisfy that need. Here's hoping Disney learns from what this film does right, as well as what it does wrong, and we get more well crafted family films in the future. I simply cannot wait for Zootopia 3. (Judy x Nick must be canon in the third and you can't change my mind.)

A good Disney Sequel! Zootopia 2 is a pleasant surprise with how seamlessly it connects to the first film, feeling like a natural continuation of the story that expands the characters and world without sacrificing the character arcs of the previous film. It's so much fun getting to see reptiles and marine mammals incorporated into the world of Zootopia. The action is exciting, the new settings are very creative, and the comedy is still hilariously fast-paced and dense. There are so many fast visual and verbal gags blank it or you miss it, including several hilarious references to other Disney movies, Succession, Silence of the Lambs, and even The Shining. We also get an insane Dik Dik joke. I like Nick and Judy's growing dynamic and conflict of reckless pursuit of justice vs snarky cynicism. Like the original, the film has a great voice cast with tons of cameos (my favorites being Danny Trejo aa the basilisk and Patrick Warburton as the Schwarzenegger-inspired horse Mayor). The beaver conspiracy theorist was funny, and I liked the Walrus humor in Marsh Town. Gary De'Snake was such a sweetheart! He's very likable and voiced so well by Ke Huy Quan and animated so well. He's so likable and innocent and curious and funny with his fast paced curious animation and innocent sounding kind hearted voice acting. That being said, I wish reptiles and especially Gary were in it longer (also more reptile species like blue tongue skins, Gila monsters, or literally any crocodilians). I also wish there was a longer time skip and more incidents show to justify the tension and threat of termination of Nick and Judy's police partnership (plus they're arguably TOO similar as they're both impulsive wild cards and the dynamic feels a bit one sided this time with Judy's recklessness being less challenged than Nick's indifference). Complaints aside, it's still a very solid and well-made movie. The main theme with the villains was on-point and there's even a good twist villain and storyline about corporate lobbying and redlining. We even get a nice little Easter egg tease after the end credits. It's a very passionate and creative movie and easily the best non-Pixar Disney sequel ever made (a low bar, but still very impressive!).

summary: A Sequel that is Equal Great as First One
text: Zootopia 2 is the animated movie I have needed to feel Disney Magic again. Shakira new song get me vibing. Judy and Nick chemistry grows stronger in this sequel, the new characters are a huge impact but Gary De Snake become my favorite new character. Disney has brought back the magic to us with is this colorful, dramatic and comedic sequel to one of the biggest blockbuster in animated movies.

'Zootopia 2' is another strong whodunnit with our likeable odd-couple pairing of Judy Hopps (Goodwin, the rabbit) and Nick Wilde (Bateman, the fox) as the anthropomorphic new police recruits. Huge returning cast - police chief/buffalo Bogo (Elba), popstar gazelle (Shakira), mole Mr Big (LaMarche) and sheep Bellweather (Slate). Plus new additions Nibbles the beaver (Feimster), Gary the snake (Huy Quan), mayor/horse Winddancer (Warburton) and the lynx's - Pawbert (Samberg) and his father Milton (Strathairn).

The case starts with the unveiling of a 100-year-old journal that is part of a cover-up to how the city of Zootopia was established - and the mystery of why there's no reptiles there. This is where conspiracy theorist Nibbles comes in to help Judy & Nick, as they're framed for helping Gary. The story is pretty obvious, and lots of parallels to immigrants helping establish the USA. There's so many locations and other animals, it's sometimes hard to keep up with all the jokes and references - Ratatouille, The Shining, Google, Babe, Cinderella, Starsky & Hutch - the list goes on.

Some of the biggest laughs are in the marsh, with the walruses and sea lions (don't call them seals!). There's probably some scary bits for young kids and it may be a bit long at 105min, but has a satisfactory ending and another end credits song by Shakira. Not quite as great as the original, but still a fun kids-film-that-adults-can-enjoy, carried by the strong performances from the 2 leads and their giant support cast.

The second part featuring the adorable duo Judy and Nick is absolutely worth watching as well. I think it's great that they reinterpreted the characters, moving them away from their prejudices. The story was exciting, funny, and full of nice messages again. The animation is really well done, the quality is very high, and I love the different worlds and colors. The only thing that's a bit annoying is Shakira's singing. But well, they wanted to have a celebrity under their banner, so I can forgive it.

I loved the first Zootopia. I've always considered it one of the few truly original Disney animations of the last 15 years that managed to be genuinely creative and memorable. I adored how it blended humor, social commentary, and a vibrant animal world full of personality. So, of course, I went into Zootopia 2 with very high expectations.

The truth is, the sequel keeps much of the charm of the original, but it never quite reaches that sense of surprise. It's like going back to a restaurant you love: the dish is still delicious, but it no longer has that thrill of the first bite. The duo Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde remains fantastic. They carry the story with the same chemistry and energy that made the first film so special. They're layered characters, full of personality, with amazing energy.

There's also a new character-a snake-who, in the promotional materials, seemed set to turn the duo into a dynamic trio. But it lacks that instant charisma you feel when a character is destined to leave a mark on a saga.

What does return, though, is what always made Zootopia shine: humor based on animal behavior, which works brilliantly again. On that front, the references to Ratatouille and The Shining were a lovely touch and genuinely made me laugh.

However, the main issue with Zootopia 2 is the lack of a surprise factor. The second act drags. It's not boring, but it didn't excite me either. Still, it's one of those films that, even without reaching the heights of the original, remains excellent family entertainment. It has rhythm, humor, beloved characters, and a creative universe that can easily entertain both kids and adults.

summary: One of Disney's Best Animated Sequels
text:
I will admit to having a little bit of a soft spot for Disney animated sequels. For as much as they have the appearance of being little more than cash grabs I still think they frequently expand the worlds and characters in fun and interesting ways, even if they're usually not as good. Zootopia 2 manages to have all of those qualities while I think actually managing to be an improvement on its predecessor.

It's just so unbelievably entertaining from start to finish and it actually manages to feel like some pretty meaningful messages woven in. Just like the first film it's the dynamic at the centre of it where most of the commentary comes from and I really appreciated the fact that the differing world views these characters have isn't just played for comedy but actually feels like it's explored in a meaningful way. It's another solid mystery, with a reveal I will totally admit I did not see coming, and they've succeed at making a world I wish existed for real. There's points in the movie where it really feels like there's a joke a minute and it never felt cheap or like it was trying too hard. I laughed out loud repeatedly and I actually thought it was quite clever in how it's executed. Ke Huy Quan is someone who is proving himself to make any new part he's in be the most wholesome aspect of the movie and that's no different here. Both his character and the movie as whole will end with you wanting to be a better person and I love it when a film gives me that feeling.

I think the Zootopia movies manage to be unbelievably entertaining whilst having a meaningful message that's woven in so seamlessly and those are the kinds of family movies that I think have the endure the longest. The first movie isn't even one of my favourites from Disney but I think the sequel actually makes me appreciate it more. Just like Inside Out 2 last year if they keep taking their time to tell meaningful new stories I truly believe that this franchise could go on forever.

Zootopia 2 follows Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde on another adventure as they discover a conspiracy revolving around reptiles in Zootopia. I really enjoyed the first Zootopia movie. I really enjoyed Zootopia 2 as well although I think the first movie is slightly better but Zootopia 2 is exactly what a sequel should be. It expands on the Zootopia world with introducing new biomes and adding reptiles into the world. Nick and Judy's relationship is about the same from the last movie. Nick is probably the weakest of the two in character development but they still have good chemistry. The story is great with some good social commentary about gentrification and appropriation. The pacing is very fast. Other than some small moments, this movie is just chase after chase so it never slows down. Add to that, the very funny puns either in the background or dialogue. You will be constantly entertained. I would say this is well worth the watch if you like the first movie.

Honestly did not remember a thing from the first movie so it was nice of them to include a summary before the actual movie started. But I would've enjoyed this even without a refresher because there's really no connection between the two movies. I liked the friendships forged between the characters and the plot twist wasn't really surprising to me - like I clocked it the moment the character appeared on screen. Anyway, this was a pretty fun watch and the humour in it was right up my alley.

New partners Officer Hopps and Wilde are struggling to find the magic they had when they broke their first case. While trying to get in sync and better understand each other, they stumble upon another case that delves deeper into Zootopia's history.

A solid animal police procedural sequel. The story explores how the differences in personality, nature, and communication can affect a relationship. The movie does expand on the city of Zootopia and its history, giving it depth and substance. There is action, suspense, comedy, and some throwback references that older people may understand. This movie is definitely for older children, but it is colorful and filled with animals that will entertain younger children as well. This is worth a night out with the family.

These 9 years of waiting were actually worth it! New interesting characters with reasonable motivations, awesome visuals of different parts of Zootopia and some humour as a cherry on top of the story.

We get what we've loved in the first part - action scenes, mystery, some characters that are not to be trusted. But here Disney goes deeper in Zootopia City and uncovers the racial bias of it really well. The reptiles being discriminated and pushed out of their homeland, prejudices and biases against them and the impact of governmental systems and celebrities on civilisation's minds - we see lots of parallels to our reality, making the story realistic and interesting to watch. The visuals of each location in the film (deserts, mountains or snowy areas) makes your eyes actually relax and enjoy the story on a higher level.

Yet, there were some parts where the plot seemed to be rushed. It didn't significantly ruined the rhythm of the story, but it's just some actions were at some point illogical.

Anyway, I really like Disney's message about racial justice and friendly behavior towards different groups of people (or "animals" if being more precise). This is what should be told to children in every cartoon to make our humanity achieve racial equality and harmony. All in all, I really recommend this movie to any age group: children could enjoy crazy plot twists, and adults could learn something new from it.

Zootropolis 2 is a continuation of the 2016 film. The sequel has its strengths as well as weaknesses. On the positive side, the creators handled the story well - it's interesting to watch the rabbit and the fox working together again. The music is good and fits the atmosphere nicely.

The story itself is rather average, which wouldn't be a problem if the film relied more on action. Here, however, the action feels weaker. Some of the jokes meant to lighten the mood don't really work.

The first film felt more mature - older viewers could relate to Judy, who was trying to succeed despite everyone doubting her. The second film has a more child-like story. It's about the fox and the rabbit learning to accept each other's mistakes and becoming better at cooperating. But the snake in the story feels almost too innocent, too "sugar-sweet." The plot twist near the end is predictable, which is a shame, because older viewers will immediately know how it's going to end.

Overall, the film will be enjoyed mainly by families with children.

summary: ootopia 2: Growing Pains in a Perfect City?
text:
Nine years after the original Zootopia redefined what a "talking animal cartoon" could be, Zootopia 2 returns to the mammal metropolis with a sequel that feels less like a reboot of the formula and more like an extended second chapter. The story once again follows Officer Judy Hopps and her partner Nick Wilde, now firmly established as a crime-fighting duo inside the ZPD. The plot framework is familiar: a new case erupts that threatens the delicate harmony of the city, pulling Judy and Nick through multiple districts, forcing them to question their assumptions, and ultimately confronting a deeper social fault line under Zootopia's seemingly inclusive surface.

The case itself is designed less as a whodunit twist machine and more as a pressure cooker. A series of incidents-suspicious crimes, growing tensions between different groups, and a wave of public anxiety-start to erode the uneasy peace established at the end of the first film. Judy, still driven by her idealism and sense of duty, pushes to treat this as a solvable problem: find the culprits, expose the scheme, restore harmony. Nick, with his older, warier streetwise instincts, senses that what they're facing isn't just a single villain but a mood, a climate, the way fear spreads through a city. As their investigation deepens, the pair confront not only suspects and red herrings, but also institutional hesitation, media distortion, and their own evolving roles as "faces of the new Zootopia."

Plotwise, Zootopia 2 is less about reconstructing some elaborate mystery and more about watching how the city responds to stress. We see old locations and new corners of Zootopia, familiar faces and fresh side characters whose lives are disrupted by the case. The film moves from comedic set-pieces-botched undercover operations, culture-clash misunderstandings, physical gags that riff on different species' sizes and abilities-to heavier sequences where crowds turn hostile, friendships fray, or long-ignored resentments bubble up. The resolution is satisfying more in its emotional logic than in pure plot surprise: the "who" and "how" are important, but the real payoff lies in what this crisis reveals about Judy, Nick, and the city they've dedicated themselves to serve.

Judy Hopps remains the moral engine of the series, but she is no longer the wide-eyed rookie hopping off the train for the first time. In this sequel, her optimism has edges. She knows how ugly things can get, she knows how much one mistake or one careless speech can hurt others, and yet she still insists on believing that institutions can be better and people can change. The film tests that belief by putting her in situations where following the rules feels inadequate or even complicit. Her character trait of stubbornness, once purely charming, now cuts both ways: sometimes it's heroism, sometimes it's a blind spot that puts others at risk. Watching her navigate that line gives the film much of its emotional texture.

Nick Wilde's arc is subtler but just as important. In the first film, his journey was about learning to trust again and stepping into the badge. Here, the tension is what it means for a once cynical outsider to become part of the system. Nick's trademark sarcasm is intact, but the jokes occasionally hide a deeper unease: he knows how quickly public opinion can turn on predators, on foxes, on anyone who doesn't fit the comforting majority image. His loyalty to Judy is never in question, but the film gently asks whether loyalty to a partner automatically equals loyalty to the entire institution behind that badge. When he hesitates, pushes back, or suggests taking a less official route, it's not just for laughs-it's a reminder of his history and the communities that still see him as "one of us" rather than "one of them."

The supporting cast remains vibrant. Chief Bogo, Clawhauser, and other returning officers give the film continuity and humor, while new characters-civilians caught in the middle, local leaders, and those tempted to exploit the crisis-serve as mirrors to different parts of Zootopia's social fabric. Even minor characters are designed with clear traits: a timid citizen whose fear is understandable but easily manipulated, a charismatic figure whose rhetoric sounds reasonable until you hear what it implies for those on the margins, a comic-relief side character who unexpectedly reveals a moral spine at a crucial moment. These small beats keep the world feeling lived-in rather than symbolic.

Visually, Zootopia 2 is everything you would expect from a big-budget Disney sequel and then some. The cinematography leans into the contrast between districts: clean, airy compositions in the city center, dense, layered frames in crowded neighborhoods, kinetic "handheld-feeling" shots in chase sequences that make the camera feel like it's weaving through fur and traffic. The color palette shifts with mood: warm, saturated hues in comedic or celebratory scenes; colder, harsher light as tensions escalate; even subtle haze and depth-of-field tricks to emphasize when our heroes feel lost in a crowd or singled out under scrutiny. The animation of fur, weather, and mass movement is almost distractingly good, but it's the smaller choices-how the camera lingers on Judy's ears drooping or Nick's tail flicking when he's nervous-that carry character emotion without dialogue.

Thematically, the film extends the first Zootopia's interest in prejudice and coexistence into a more mature space: not "do prejudices exist?" but "what happens after the big apology speech is over?" It tackles how fear rebrands itself as "common sense," how calls for security can be weaponized, and how even well-meaning people can retreat into their own groups when things get tense. It also quietly explores burnout and responsibility: what does it cost Judy and Nick, emotionally, to be symbols? Are they allowed to be tired, wrong, or scared, or must they always be examples for others? The movie doesn't resolve all of these questions neatly, but it at least raises them in ways both kids and adults can feel.

On the lighter side, the film continues the franchise's tradition of stuffing the frame with Easter eggs. Background billboards, store names, and movie posters parody both real-world pop culture and other Disney properties; there are playful nods for those who know the studio's catalog, and a few blink-and-you'll-miss-them gags involving familiar silhouettes and musical cues. The end-credits sting, a small but affectionate extra scene, doesn't hard-tease a plot for Zootopia 3 so much as leave the door invitingly ajar: the city is still growing, new neighbors are still arriving, and there are clearly more stories to tell if the studio chooses to return.

As a whole, Zootopia 2's strengths are clear. It respects its audience, refuses to reduce complex social dynamics to simple slogans, and gives its central duo real emotional work to do. The world-building remains rich and funny, the pacing rarely drags, and the balance between comedy and heavier material is carefully managed. Its weaknesses are, perhaps inevitably, those of many high-quality sequels: it lacks the shock of the new, some beats feel like variations on themes you already know, and a couple of side characters could have used more room to breathe. Viewers looking for a tight mystery might find the investigation more atmospheric than intricate.

From a neutral perspective, Zootopia 2 doesn't dethrone the original, but it doesn't need to. It operates as a thoughtful, entertaining continuation that deepens the city and its inhabitants rather than trying to outdo every twist and punchline. For fans who have waited years to step back into Zootopia, it offers exactly what a good sequel should: a sense of coming home, with just enough fractures in the fa√ßade to remind you that even in a "perfect" city, growing up-and growing together-never really ends.

summary: Hugely enjoyable movie for kids and adults
text: I sincerely hope it's not another 9 years before the next one. These movies have to be the best thing Disney are doing at the moment. It's one of those movies that kids will love but parents (or adults without kids) will also get massive enjoyment out of. The references, message, animation, voice acting and writing are all 10/10.

Time is a crazy thing. I can't believe it's been nearly 10 years since Disney animation released the smash hit ZOOTOPIA, a "bunny-cop" movie about a rabbit joining forces with a fox to solve a case in a world full of animals. Now, ZOOTOPIA 2 is finally out of the hat (yes, I'm trying to cram as many animal puns in here as I can). The story takes place just one week after the original. Judy Hopps (Ginnifer Goodwin) and Nick Wilde (Jason Bateman) are now partners on the police force, the first mixed species team ever. Everybody around them is skeptical of their partnership, but the dynamic duo is determined to prove them wrong. They pick up a new case and are immediately embroiled in a conspiracy involving a snake named Gary De'Snake (Ke Huy Quan) and how Zootopia is able to cohabitate all kinds of land mammals. Along for the ride are new and funny characters such as the beaver podcaster and conspiracy theorist Nibbles Maplestick (Fortune Feimster). This movie is just as amazing as the original, perhaps a smidge funnier. It's full of funny animal puns/jokes, references (some not just for kids), and an extremely heartfelt message of friendship. Another, more adult message in here is about how a group of animals were wiped off the map by another group. I feel like whenever Disney tries to make an animated musical these days, it fails. Yes, there is one song in this, but it's actually catchy and good. I love how there are entirely too many known voices in this, definitely too many to type out here. Despite the familiar buddy-cop story, the core is still Judy and Nick's relationship. It's complex, authentic, and it brings out some emotion. This movie is on par with K-POP DEMON HUNTERS as my favourite animated movie of the year, also probably one of the best Disney sequels out there. Overall, ZOOTOPIA 2 was well worth the wait, and I'm very excited about where they can go next. Take the whole family and stay through the credits!

summary: Zootopia 2016 but a lot tamer & weaker
text:
I am grossly disappointed. They upted the ante when it comes to the visual gags & animal related jokes which gets unfunny very quickly. The old characters are so shoehorned in & the new characters are way weaker than the two protagonists. The snake is nowhere near as interesting as Judy from the first film, whose journey to make it into the ZPD through will & hard work despite her apparent size is many folds more inspiring & clever than any arcs & themes brought up in Z2.

Same goes for the clever carnivore vs herbivore race allegory from Z1, we get sth similar but 1) it is a rehash but soo sooo much weaker 2) didn't say anything that hasn't been said a thousand times already 3) made the message extra clear through dialogue instead of letting the audience figure out for themselves -

Disney has sold out to the kids audience since the 2010s & it is never more apparent here. This sterility goes further than this. Remember the darker themes in Z1? Mind control, cannibalism, blood (climax). There is barely a scratch in Z2. You would have thought a 2016 product as cleverly crafted as Zootopia would survive that, but no~

Structurally, the opening was so fast paced & I would much prefer Z1 where you begin in Judy's hometown so you can understand her motivation; this makes the payoff later on more impactful. As a result, I am so emotionally disinterested by the third act. The ending felt like impassionate homework.

Z1 was such a great theme & the sequel automatically is granted much potential. I don't think the sequel should take place just a week after the events of Z1, I would have loved to see how the character dynamics organically develop behind the scenes in like say two years time, or the how the zeitgeist changes to better represent modern America (Z1's crowning achievement), and all the new issues that spout from a melting plot of race & cultures, instead of rehashing.

Z2 is sterile & dumbed down version of Z1's timeless concept & social commentary. Bush traded nuance for jokes & safety. Zootopia is a lesser place now than nine years ago.

Why on Earth did they make us wait 9 years for this sequel, it was so good.

It did everything a sequel is meant to do; expand upon our understanding of the characters and universe they operate in, give us complex thematic elements that both child and parents will be able to relate to and also manage to give us some new fresh characters, as well as a hilarious use of comedy. Zootopia 2 truly does it all.

Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde have since entered into a turbulent partnership at the ZPD, much to the chagrin of everyone else around them. They shouldn't work as partners but some how they do, but that may have something to do will the fact that they aren't being 100% honest with each other about how well things are actually going.

They're in denial.

They lack of hindsight quickly sees them land in boiling water with Chief Bogo and indeed the rest of the police crew as they wreck havoc all over Zootopia in the name of catching their man. Such the event also gives Judy the scent of a new mystery creating over the horizon, this time in the shape of a snake. Reptiles have not been seen in Zootopia for almost 100 years, akin to the fact that no one trusts a snake. They seem to have no place in the Zootopia that we have already seen.

The snake in question is lovingly voiced by Ke Huy Quan, giving him the most goofy persona imaginable, already changing the audience's, and Judy's, perception of this so called fanged menaces. It's one of the more expanded upon themes from the first film, that the prejudices that people believe have unfortunate consequences, leading into one of the new concepts that this sequel implores to explore; displacement.

Many people have already drawn many a parallel to the events happening in Gaza at this time, and also the continued threatening prescence of ICE detaining people illegally. It is revealed at the end that the nefarious snow leopards of Tundra Town deceived the entirety of Zootopia and used the fear-mongers technique of a supposed venomous fanging to sway public opinion.

The accuracy of all the different cities that make up Zootopia is insane. The ability to animate all those intricacies and still manage to make sure that the important details shine through in order to progress the story. We get to see a lot more of Tundra Town in this instalment, as well as some interesting new environments like Marsh Market and the illicit reptilian bar.

It's a direction that we all knew we were heading in when Nick and Judy were announced as partners at the conclusion of the first film; that their differing perspectives may be the root cause of their downfall. And it was... but only for sometime. They are actually made to attend partner therapy at the beginning of the film and while it proves to be a little bit of a bust because they just aren't really to be honest with each other. That heartfelt moment comes on down line.

summary: Let Us Paws & Reflect: Disney Tackles Prejudices Again In Zootopia
text:
Walt Disney Animation Studios has made a handful of sequels to some of their animated films for nearly the last decade. Films like Wreck-It Ralph, Frozen, and Moana all spawned a sequel and released in theaters. But for some reason, they felt unfocused in terms of storytelling and proper character development. However. What I really like about animated sequels is world building. While you can get returning characters being thrusted into a new adventure and also introducing new characters along the way, story is always important and should not be ignored. Now as for Zootopia 2? It remains focused on that. I mean, it still has the same material as the 2016 original in terms of prejudicial themes and discrimination, but what I believe adds to it here is immigration.

About a week after bunny cop Judy Hopps and streetsmart con artist fox Nick Wilde cracked their first case together. Nick is now an official police officer and working alongside Judy in their next assignment. In this case tracking down a wanted fugitive identified as Gary De'Snake. With the first reptile showing himself in the presence of Zootopia inhabitants, there's more to his presence than initially believed. Gary knows he's trying to do the right thing, but he'll need the generous assistance of Nick and Judy to set things right, even if it means the duo is risking their own careers as law enforcers.

Stars Jason Bateman and Ginnifer Goodwin reprise the roles of Nick and Judy respectively, including a few other returning characters voiced by Idris Elba, Alan Tudyk, Nate Torrance, and Jenny Slate. But new to the cast like Ke Huy Quan (The Goonies, Everything Everywhere All At Once) is proving to be a worthy addition in this all animal cast. The entire movie is also stacked with an all-star cast of actors either for voice cameo or minor role. I can go on forever about the Disney Easter eggs and other cameos. Fortunately, these don't distract from the story at all. I like the message that it was trying to display. It's like don't judge a book by its cover. On the outside, it's about the witty humor and gags that made the characters likable while on their journey. However, on the inside. It's like we delve deep into the lore and depth within this caper. While the kids will enjoy the lightheartedness and funny moments along with their parents, it will make adults look more into the context of what the story is really trying to convey.

There's a balance of humor and seriousness that had me remain engaged, so I wasn't bored at all. Zootopia 2 is without a doubt a worthy successor helmed by returning director Jared Bush. Awesome job from the cast and crew!

summary: Poor Nick is a Secondary Character
text:
The graphics, animation, and visuals are all nice and interesting, and you do look forward to seeing how they build this turtle neighborhood, reptiles neighborhood, etc. But I'm not sure I'd say it's the best storyline ever. The first 15-20 minutes are about the couple again and their struggle to be believed, their differences, etc. (we already had that and solved it in "season 1").

It almost felt like Nick was a secondary character to Judy. She's the one fighting, getting the calls from her parents, etc. Most of what we see of him is just his perspective on what's happening, without really connecting it back to his character development, personal backstory, or anything deeper.

Then there's this whole snake/lynx drama that was fine but very predictable and kind of... generative? Like, it feels like you could reuse the same template: just bring another villain and another victim, write a similar plot, and boom, you have "season 3." The dialogue and jokes also felt flat and sometimes forced.

Maybe I'm being harsh because it's a Disney production? But I remember I actually dozed off while watching. It had no real edge or feeling of urgency. You don't feel like this plot is super close to the main characters or really affecting them. Like, if they got caught, what's the worst that would happen for most of the movie? They'd get fired. (Yes, their lives were endangered toward the end, but still.) Going this far to save a stranger snake from a stranger villain didn't feel like the strongest plot.

If it were me, I might've written a villain who's related to Nick, or even his own brother, and have Nick and Judy go through real moral dilemmas where they, and we, actually learn something or change as people by the end. Right now the "development" we get is that Nick says he loves her and cares about her, like, no sh? I'm not saying every character has to have massive growth every time, but there's a lot of space and creativity here to do something bigger, and they just went with a generic, overused plot.

My kids (6 and 12) watched it with me and they didn't like it either. I'd give this a 4/10.

ZOOTOPIA 2 stays right on track with its predecessor. I still can't help but wonder why it took almost ten years to finally get this sequel.

Let's start with the animation: it looks awesome. This world is just so much fun to spend time in. There are some really nice, unique set pieces, and I still love the cleverness of having big and small animals living in the same space. We explore a couple new areas, though I wish we had explored more. I did really dig the marsh and all of the animals and hijinks that came with it.

The story picks up right after the first movie. Judy and Nick are now officially partners in the police department, and that's where this movie truly shines. Their dynamic is on point. This is a full-on buddy-cop comedy, and I'm a sucker for those - and it works incredibly well here. Sure, it's an animated family movie, but I could totally picture this story playing out in live action. We also get a solid lineup of new characters that fit perfectly into the world, but Judy and Nick are still the standouts. Their relationship is genuinely beautiful and remains the heart of the film.

The voice cast, both returning and new, once again delivers across the board, but what really brings this movie to life is the humor. I found this to be absolutely hilarious - tons of great jokes, gags, and laughs throughout.

Overall, ZOOTOPIA 2 is a worthy sequel that sits right alongside the original, hitting all the right beats. The whole family had a blast with it, and I definitely recommend checking it out. And with that post-credit scene... here's hoping we don't have to wait until 2035 to get a trilogy!

Thanksgiving is an excellent time full of turkey, family, togetherness, and animal puns. That's right, as has been tradition for many years now, Disney Animation releases a movie right before Thanksgiving to capitalize on children being off school and families getting together for the holidays. This year, we have a sequel to the 2016 animated hit Zootopia, and with the entire cast returning, it'll be a surefire box-office hit. I very much enjoyed the first Zootopia back in 2016. It was an entertaining kids' movie with some great adult/real-world themes that were incorporated very well into the plot. Looking back on it, it isn't the MOST rewatchable animated movie, but it still was a very entertaining film. There was a lot to work with if you wanted to make a sequel. In the end, this stands as one of the better Disney sequels we've gotten from them over the years!

Zootopia 2 takes place merely one week after the first film ended, with Judy Hopps (voiced by Ginnifer Goodwin) and Nick Wilde (voiced by Jason Bateman) as newly appointed partners at the Zootopia Police Department after their first major case with the predators. They are clashing with their coworkers and their Chief Bogo (voiced by Idris Elba), as their personalities/methods are so different that they mess up many things on their cases. Bogo tells them that if they can't work together correctly, he will split them up. Things start to get crazy when Judy discovers a snake skin in a case they do, and even learns that snakes/reptiles haven't been in Zootopia for many, many years.

When Judy and Nick infiltrate the Zootenial Gala, they discover a snake named Gary (voiced by Ke Huy Quan), and they are suddenly framed for working with Gary. And a mystery unravels just like the first movie, with Judy and Nick on the run this time from the Police department and a Lynx family who have some beef with the snakes. It's up to Judy and Nick to solve this mystery, but will they overcome their partner issues to crack the case?

So another typical buddy cop duo/mystery movie just like the previous Zootopia movie, but what sets this apart from the first movie is that element of being on the run, and even some other social hidden meaning that made the first movie so great, this time dealing with who really was the founder of Zootopia and why have reptiles not been seen for decades? You also have a very different dynamic between Nick and Judy as they try to navigate their being partners and how truly opposite they are. The story was outstanding and very heartwarming, with even some twists and turns I didn't expect! The script is very well written, with genuinely funny lines, puns, and scenes.

This is one of the funniest Disney films I've seen in a while, and I enjoyed so many creative ways we got to explore more of this Zootopia world. Not only was the dynamic between these characters very well done, but I also enjoyed how intriguing this narrative was with the snakes and the lynx family. It really made a fun/enjoyable movie while also bringing in many real-world comparisons that anyone would make. Exactly like the first movie, and that's why this film sits on par with the first Zootopia movie (with the side note that this film was way funnier).

The only criticism is that it doesn't quite reach the massive scale of the best Disney movies, where you feel emotional, or the high highs of the best Disney animated films. It's a highly entertaining movie, but I don't expect this to be an annual rewatch or the best animated film of the decade, for sure. It is funny, thought-provoking, fun, adventurous, and, in many ways, a very well-done children's movie. The fact that this movie has grossed $556 million worldwide and that my screening was PACKED shows it will do exceptionally well.

Overall, it deserves to do that well! When you have very mediocre sequels like Frozen 2 and Moana 2, and even a terrible sequel like Ralph Breaks the Internet, it was such a breath of fresh air to have this come out and succeed where those sequels failed. It is an excellent continuation of the first Zootopia, sitting right on par with that film and even featuring better comedy. I really had a great time with Zootopia, and know this is going to be a film that kids and adults will enjoy this Thanksgiving/Holiday season. I give this an 8/10.

If you liked the first Zootopia, you're absolutely going to enjoy this one. Zootopia 2 takes things in a surprisingly bold direction - leaning way more into an action-packed, James Bond-style adventure. We're talking elaborate car chases, slick spy-tech sequences, and high-energy fight scenes that crank the intensity way beyond what we saw nine years ago in the original. Not that the movie is bad - far from it - it's just a shock to the system at first because of how different this sequel feels.

Once again, we're blessed with the phenomenal voice talents of Ginnifer Goodwin (Judy Hopps) and Jason Bateman (Nick Wilde), who slip right back into their roles with the same charm, wit, and chemistry that made the first film such a hit. Judy and Nick are back on the beat, forced to prove - once again - that a bunny and a fox can save a city, especially when the odds are stacked against them.

The Supporting Cast & Newcomers

The world expands even further thanks to a loaded supporting cast. Returning favorites like Idris Elba, Jenny Slate, Bonnie Hunt, and Nate Torrence help keep that classic Zootopia flavor intact. But it's the newcomers who really inject fresh energy into the sequel - including Ke Huy Quan as Gary and the sleek new villain De'Snake.

This time, the adventure pushes far outside the familiar boundaries of Zootopia, taking us into previously unseen regions filled with new species, new environments, and a conspiracy that ties everything together. It's honestly one of the coolest expansions of this world that Disney has done in a while.

Is It Better Than the First?

This is where audiences might be split.

Some will say this entry is slightly better because of its bigger scale, sharper action, and deeper mystery. Others may prefer the grounded emotional storytelling and social commentary of the original. Both takes are valid - it really depends on what kind of movie experience you're looking for.

But one thing is universal: Judy and Nick remain one of Disney's strongest, most lovable duos ever. And after this sequel, they absolutely deserve a third film. Their chemistry is just too good to stop here.

Final Thoughts

If you loved the first movie, there's a very strong chance you're going to enjoy this one as well. It's fun, fast, charming, and packed with heart - just delivered in a new, action-spy flavor.

So buckle up, enjoy the ride, and welcome back to the wild world of Zootopia.

summary: We still yearned for this Zootopia
text:
In 2025, as globalisation faced unprecedented challenges, we still yearned for this Zootopia.

The 2016 Rio Olympics and the release of Zootopia1 epitomised the 2010s-an era that may well stand as humanity's closest approach to a community with a shared future in our generation's memory. It was precisely this decade that gave birth to Zootopia1, a film brimming with boundless optimism. People yearned to further dismantle societal discrimination and prejudice, even when such divisions fell far short of becoming antagonistic conflicts.

By late 2019, the world rapidly succumbed to the threat of a virus. Persistent regional conflicts and global disorder did not abate with the pandemic's end; instead, the world plunged into an endless post-pandemic era. Nine years after being moved by Zootopia, can we still believe in that beautiful utopia from nine years ago?

Zootopia 2 not only arrives on schedule but delivers a timely response to our era. Where the first film explored tensions between carnivores and herbivores, the sequel confronts the divide between mammals and reptiles. The former stemmed from 'legitimate' and 'mild' discrimination, while the latter points directly towards 'illegitimate' and 'escalated' confrontation. The Zootopia creative team understood they could no longer stitch together a flawless utopia. Instead, they chose to deconstruct Zootopia's societal foundations and rebuild a more refined society.

Though human society comprises a single species biologically, deconstructing and reconstructing it to transform and perfect our world proves infinitely more challenging than shaping the diverse, multi-species ecosystem of Zootopia. Yet in this era of unprecedented upheaval, confronting a society where contradictions intensify daily, humanity has no alternative but deconstruction and reconstruction-even if it entails prolonged growing pains. History has taught us: human progress is never smooth sailing or linear ascent, but a complex spiral of negation upon negation-a unity of forward momentum and tortuous twists. Even though the contradictions within human society can never be attributed to a single evil family, as in the film's plot, Zootopia 2 still chooses to gently present reality to its audience through the lens of a fairy tale. For if we no longer believe in the existence of utopias like Zootopia, the new generation of the 21st century will only be able to recall that world that once came infinitely close to utopia through Zootopia 1.

At least for now, people can still escape the harsh realities of the world and enter this vibrant utopia; looking ahead, humanity will continue to yearn for this hopeful Zootopia, believing that a better world will ultimately arrive.

At first glance, it's more fluffy animals, funny gags, and Judy, who's still shorter than her ambitions. But beneath the furry surface lies a hard-hitting film noir about fake news, collective trauma, and how a "perfect" society is held together with well-worn old lies. The message isn't the usual "just be nice to each other" platitudes, but rather: empathy is hard work, and every utopia must first expose its own founding myths as propaganda, otherwise, it's game over. Kids get the action and the funny sloths, while adults sit by, gulping, because the film knows exactly how quickly "But we've always been tolerant!" can become a weapon. Technically perfect, emotionally honest, and yet every five minutes a gag pops up that makes the little ones squeal with delight. The rarest of all family films: one that takes both generations seriously without lying to either.

Zootopia 2 surprises by delivering a sequel that easily surpasses the original. The visuals are absurdly detailed, realistic without losing charm, and the animation reaches a technical level that even Disney rarely achieves. The expansion of the world: new biomes, new species, and a natural evolution of the theme of prejudice, shows that the sequel exists for a real reason, not just for profit.

The plot occasionally slips into the generic, but the pace is great, the humor works, and Michael Giacchino's score ties everything together elegantly. In the end, it's an animated blockbuster that entertains, impresses, and paves the way for a franchise that could be very lucrative.

A sequel that not only respects the original, but surpasses it.

This is the sequel the original deserved. Judy and Nick are partners, and the city's plans for expansion are upset by a snake. Which begs the question, where have the reptiles been? Watch to find out, and by all means, enjoy.

'Zootopia 2' is an absolute home run for all moviegoers, with an amusing film proving that Disney can still wow audiences of all ages with its combination of great storytelling and energetic animation. Clever as ever, the writing shines with its witty humor displayed throughout, yet the film never chooses laughs over proper levity. Not only is this sequel consistent in maintaining the first film's smart charm, but there's also a thematically resonant narrative that is sure to win the hearts of the viewers. Jason Bateman's 'Nick Wilde' and Ginnifer Goodwin's 'Judy Hopps' provide their usual magnetic voice work and even bring the tandem further into its iconic form. Ke Huy Quan's 'Gary De' Snake' is also a tremendous addition to the cast with a character whose impact capitalizes on being the champion of the oppressed. The soundtrack is catchy and elevates the film by inspiring an excellent third act, having some emotional stakes that culminate in compelling moments between characters. Engaging throughout, funny, and most of all, a quality sequel, Disney's 'Zootopia 2' is a thoughtful, animated feature that all families would enjoy watching in theaters.
