summary: Zootopia 2 and it's laughably bad plot
text:
To start this off, I enjoyed the movie. There are a lot of things to love about Zootopia 2, but you really must shut your brain off to get there, because the moment you start thinking about how the characters and institutions behave, the story starts falling apart, and nowhere is that clearer than in what the movie does to Nick and Judy.

A toxic relationship is a relationship where one person repeatedly harms the other through manipulation and control by isolating them, creating dependency, and shifting responsibility, so the harmed person feels obligated to stay and "protect" them even as the relationship damages their safety, stability, and connections. Typical traits include isolation (pulling you away from others), love-bombing (intense affection used to secure loyalty), manufactured crises that force constant rescuing, guilt and pressure when you try to set boundaries, and externalizing blame ("the real problem is everyone else," so you must fight outsiders instead of questioning the relationship). Throughout the story, Judy drags Nick along on increasingly dangerous missions, and her choices repeatedly almost get them both killed, yet the film treats her recklessness like determination and treats Nick's hesitation like weakness, even though Nick is the one thinking about survival, consequences, and the basic reality that "doing the right thing" does not protect you from getting buried by the world's systems. Nick tries multiple times to reason with her, urging her to step back, even suggesting taking Mr. Big's deal as an exit, and realistically he probably can't take that path without Judy since Mr. Big only likes her, but the point is that Nick is constantly forced into Judy's spiral and the movie wants us to interpret it as loyalty rather than what it actually looks like: a friend being dragged into danger while being emotionally cornered into accepting it.

Judy's behavior is toxic. The message, taken at face value, is that you should follow your partner into near death, commit crimes, if necessary, destroy your connections with everyone else in your life, and it will all magically work out. Nick is expected to apologize or bend, while Judy never clearly apologizes to him for dragging him into situations that almost get him killed, and if the beaver hadn't been placed within the same cell block as him(which shouldn't have happened as they are opposite genders), he would have been killed by the Lynxley family, which the movie barely acknowledges beyond using it as another beat to push the plot forward, without giving Judy a real moment of accountability or letting the consequences breathe. The closest Judy gets to addressing any of this is when she confesses her feelings about how much Nick means to her, saying "no one else in the world matters to me more than you(Nick) do either," and that line is supposed to show loyalty and care, but in context it paints a disturbing picture because caring about someone should not mean ignoring their fear, dragging them into near-death danger, and risking their life over and over again without any serious reflection afterward.

In The Hunchback of Notre Dame, Judge Frollo is the Minister of Justice of Paris, is tasked with protecting the peace. He uses that position to try to purge the Romani people from the city, and he does it in a way that leads to the burning of Paris. When he meets Phoebus, the war hero, he doesn't assume an automatic agreement. He takes him up to the balcony, shows him his view of Paris, and vents about how he sees the city and how the Romani "threaten" it. He doesn't say kill or anything of the like instead he using word like rid. He talks about order, justice, and cleansing, which is exactly how real politicians operate: they avoid the ugly part directly and wrap it in duty and morality. He's also this was a test for Phoebus, watching how he reacts, seeing how far he can pull him along without stating his real endgame outright.

Now look at Cattrick Lynxley in Zootopia 2. He's the head of a powerful, wealthy family. When Gary De Snake kidnaps him and steals a priceless artifact, Judy saves him and Nick knocks Gary out. Cattrick's immediate response is: "Kill the snake we'll burn the journal, if he wants it, it is dangerous and you two will file a report that he attacked us..." There's no build-up, no euphemism, no test, just a blunt request, which obviously is denied, for an execution and a falsified report dropped in front of two cops he barely knows, one of whom is famous citywide for taking down two corrupt mayors in the last movie. It's supposed to show how corrupt and ruthless he is, but it ends up just showing this movie's laughably bad writing.

Later, when Nick is caught, Cattrick hints that he has enough influence for bad things to happen to people in prison. That's all the scene needs: the implication that he can make problems "go away" without saying it outright. But that only makes the earlier "Kill the snake..." moment feel even worse. If he's the kind of person who works through systems, pressure, and connections, then openly demanding Judy allow him to kill Gary on the spot still reads like the movie handing the villain a megaphone instead of letting him be believable. Cattrick could have won if he only let the snake get arrested and then used the connections; he implies he has on the snake.

The twist villain, Pawbert Lynxley, is fine. He functions as a twist as the first movie had one, so they had to also have one. The patent part is shaky. Utility patents like the climate wall end after 20 years. A claim that a single utility patent from 100 years ago still controls everything doesn't make much sense. If the Lynxleys still have control over the wall a century later, the story needs a different explanation: ownership of the infrastructure, contracts, political concessions, control over maintenance, or constantly updated improvements. Even inside the movie's own framing, it raises a weird question. If the Lynxleys were already rich enough to be investors, of a project that would cost over 10s of billions of dollars (as well how would they make any profit from this wall) why would the first Lynxley kill the snake inventor for the patent instead of buying it? Wealthy power structures usually purchase, co-opt, or bury inventions legally when they can. Murdering the inventor feels less like careful legacy-building and more like the writers forcing a "dark history" beat because it sounds dramatic.

Then there's the kidnapping from Judy's point of view. Gary De Snake kidnaps Cattrick and steals a priceless artifact. Those are felonies. When Judy corners him, he launches into a sob story, similar to how Nick talked his way through situations in the first film. The difference is that Nick, at that point, wasn't a kidnapper holding a stolen artifact. Gary is a felon, armed because of his fangs, and a direct threat. Judy was tricked once already in the first movie; you'd expect some kind of development. Instead, she starts to fall for the same type of emotional appeal again. On top of that, these scenes land at almost the same point in the runtime as equivalent beats in the first movie, which makes the sequel feel like it's copying the original structure instead of doing anything new with it.

Finally, the reptile ban logic is weak. The movie treats reptiles like a class that "makes sense" to exclude, but the justification is basically that 100 years ago a single snake killed a turtle and that led to all reptiles being banned, why not just vipers or have them defanged. Also, if there's genuine demand for safe spaces for reptiles, demand gets met. If the city blocks them legally, then there would be a lot of laws they would have to change but to think such law would still be in place; however, laws are often hidden in what they are meant to do.

summary: Rare case when the 2nd is better!
text: Disney hasn't made a movie like this in years. Probably since Coco. There's been stuff, yes, but nothing that made the viewers really "feel" the universe, connect with the characters, follow a great story. This movie has it. And the pacing is just frantic, you really can't miss a minute, it's full of twists and surprises, has you on the edge of your seat with some really action packed scenes like the water pipe, the hut, and more. My daughter is 6 and obviously lost in some plot details but she loved it anyway. Honestly, my expectations weren't high, after all, the first one was the novelty, how were they going to keep it fresh when the premise of animals living like humans has already been seen? Encanto was not bad but not great, and I had great hopes with Moana 2 but it didn't even come close to a quarter of what the first one was. But Zootopia 2 did the trick, the writer managed to build on what we had seen before, taking old elements and adding new ones. It does the trick. Loved it. And the message of peace is strong.

First off, it's nice to see Jason Bateman working again. ;)
To be sure, this installment was, dare I say, a little deeper than the original. The themes of friendship, partnership, and belonging that were covered in the first one were amplified several notches for the sequel.

One thing that worked for me was the James Bond/Mission Impossible nature of this story, which was especially noticeable when Judy and Nick were dressed up for the gala (in the interest of going undercover).

The set pieces were stunningly beautiful, and showed what human beings can do with an idea, hours and hours and hours of animation, music, editing, and more editing to create something that will take your breath away.

Much like the first Zootopia, they really went all out to collect a "deep bench" of voice talent, including about a half dozen SNL performers, Disney/Pixar alums, and some fun surprises like Michael J. Fox and Robert Irwin.

All told, I enjoyed this very much and wouldn't mind taking another look to really appreciate the non-AI artistry.

The sequel performs quite well, but it didn't significantly exceed the expectations I set when purchasing my ticket two weeks in advance. My deepest sympathies to those who couldn't see it!

Character Development (B+)

The good news is that the core characters, Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde, remain true to their established selves. The new additions are passable, though online consensus about them being somewhat flat is accurate. The main issue lies with these new faces: one (Gary) has a simplistic but understandable motivation, and the other (Nibbles) is a good-natured character seemingly without any clear motivation at all.

Judy and Nick's depth largely rests on the foundation of the first film; viewed in isolation, the sequel doesn't fully capture their richness. I believe the film suffers from having too many characters. Combining the arcs of the beaver Nibbles Maplestick and the civet Gary might have resulted in a more complete central supporting role. As for the rest of the ensemble, they mainly serve as comedic filler-a style I personally enjoy as it gives a sense of continuity and connection to the broader Zootopia world.

Plot & Pacing (C+)

The plot certainly feels rushed at points. There's a definite sense of over-padding in the setup, with the main resolution crammed into the final twenty minutes. It's hard not to suspect the lengthy buildup contains ideas the writers loved but couldn't bear to cut, or perhaps was simply an excuse for Disney to showcase its dazzling animation capabilities.

The primary storyline is largely sound, except for one segment where the fast development felt solely designed to highlight Judy's individual skill. The real flaws are in the subplots and dropped threads, such as: What was the deal with Mayor Winddancer? Was he truly dealt with? And was the Pig Officer who fired the final shot truly compromised?

Tone & Theme (The Major Flaw) (C-)

This is where the sequel truly falters. The tone is excessively humorous, losing the undercurrent of subdued despair and existential melancholy that permeated the first film. The original's subtle darkness was essential; it was what made Judy's spirit and her optimistic drive to break down stereotypes and combat societal prejudice so valuable. It showcased a small figure fighting against the tide and rebelling against her destiny.

In this film, Judy often feels like she's creating trouble unnecessarily, as many complications could have been avoided. It positions itself as a police story but strips away the essence of police work, portraying its two officer protagonists and the entire ZPD as clueless buffoons largely irrelevant to the plot's core. The sequel devolves into a pure adventure story, losing all thematic depth.

If this script were for a film like The Bad Guys 2, it would be a perfect fit. But for a Zootopia film, I believe it falls short of the mark.

A Final Note on Romance (A+)

While the visuals didn't feel like a noticeable upgrade and occasionally bordered on visual fatigue, the emotional payoff was excellent. Compared to the "space kiss" in The Bad Guys 2, the subtle, mutual need and care between Judy and Nick-only explicitly stated at the very end-is far more exhilarating. I absolutely adore this kind of emotional development. Give me more!

That's it.

I absolutely love Zootopia 1. It's a well thought-out and well-paced classic with hilarious, memorable characters. Therefore, I had high hopes for the second part. It could be that I was on a bad mood that day, but I was really disappointed with Zootopia 2. The story is very thin and only unravels as the movie progresses. The new characters feel tacked on -- the horse character could have been removed altogether from the movie with no consequences. The number of animal-related puns is just excessive. Every possible word is replaced with a pun. In general I'm a fan of puns, but this is just too much. But the biggest problem of the movie is the pacing: everything happens way too fast and there is no time to breathe. This is like an animated version of Mission Impossible, but without the charisma.

I will rewatch the original, not this.

It's hard to believe it's already been 9 years since Zootopia came out. The timing makes the Season 2 release feel a little like a cash grab. The fact that Part 2 picks up just a few weeks after Part 1 also creates a weird disconnect where the characters are frozen in time, but the audience watching is almost a decade older, and even the voice actors have aged in real life.

If the first movie was about the American dream and a young adult stepping into the modern world with innocence and idealism, Season 2 tackles more mature themes while still keeping the light, fun, and accessible vibe. Just like in the original, we get a self-contained mystery that lets the two main characters travel and explore. This time, though, the world feels bigger with more international and clear parodies of various cultures and countries.

The plot structure works if the goal is to focus on the characters' internal and psychological struggles, and that part is genuinely executed well. But considering what the main duo achieved in Season 1, I expected the citizens of Zootopia to treat them with more respect this time.

The film introduces several relevant topics: Masculinity, fatherhood, podcast culture, conspiracy theories, and cultural immersion, but mostly at a beginner level. Not in a shallow way, but more as acknowledgment and reflection rather than deep exploration. The villain is a bit underwhelming, although their motivation is surprisingly refreshing and actually caught me off guard.

The story moves through many places, and while each location is solid and enjoyable, none of them feel truly outstanding or memorable. And that kind of summarizes the whole movie for me: I felt decently satisfied throughout: Never disappointed, but never blown away either. It's basically Zootopia 1 with expanded scope and a few tweaks to the formula.

Overall, it's a good movie. But I'm skeptical of Disney's habit of endlessly recycling old IPs. I'm perfectly happy with Zootopia 1 and Zootopia 2, and I wouldn't be surprised if they make a third. What I don't want to see is a live-action version or a prequel just for the sake of milking the franchise.

summary: The First Zootopia was PERFECTION this one is not
text: After almost 10 years a new Zootopia was being released and so I thought Disney took their time to really outshine the first one as it's a top 5 Disney movie for me. Unfortunately, it falls in the same trap as other sequels where they try to incorporate more characters and crazier plots. The plot just moved too fast and nothing really stuck. Zootopia 2 is exactly what a sequel should be, and honestly, it might be even better than the first film. I walked out of the cinema feeling completely satisfied.

The story focuses on the tricky reality of Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde's partnership. Seeing them go through those awkward ZPD partner therapy sessions only makes their bond stronger, and their dynamic is interesting to watch.

In addition, the song is catchy, the voice acting was good for the characters, and the whole thing was memorable. It was not inappropriate like some other reviews had claimed. You should definitely watch it in the cinema.

Zootopia 2 is a fun, well-crafted sequel. The animation is gorgeous, the humor lands, and Nick and Judy's chemistry remains the heart of the franchise. As pure entertainment, it delivers.

But I left the theater conflicted about its message.

The film sets up a meaningful arc about heroism. Nick, the cynical fox, appears poised to learn what it truly means to be a police officer-to serve something larger than yourself. Early on, he tells Judy that dying for a case isn't worth it. She looks disappointed. The movie seems to be asking: can Nick grow beyond his self-protective instincts?

His answer, in the climax, is that while he wouldn't die for the job, he would die for Judy-his partner, his family.

Now, I understand the appeal of this resolution. There's a real philosophical tradition that sees personal love as the foundation of moral life, not a departure from it. And Nick learning to be vulnerable with someone, to commit to another person after years of isolation-that is growth. The movie earns those emotional beats.

But I wonder if it stops one step short.

The best stories about duty and service show characters extending their circle of care outward-learning that the love they have for one person can teach them to love more broadly. Nick's arc suggests the opposite: that personal attachment is where moral obligation ends rather than where it begins.

Consider what the film is saying to its young audience: a police officer's highest loyalty should be to the people they personally love, not to the community they've sworn to protect. In isolation, that's a reasonable human sentiment. But as a lesson-especially in a story about public service-it risks endorsing a kind of selective loyalty that, scaled up, looks more like tribalism than heroism.

I don't think the filmmakers intended this reading. And maybe I'm asking too much of a kids' movie. But the original Zootopia aimed high with its themes about prejudice and didn't flinch. This sequel sets up an equally ambitious question about sacrifice and civic duty, then settles for an easier answer.

Zootopia 2 promised a story about becoming a hero. It delivered a story about becoming a devoted friend. That's not nothing-but it's also not quite what it could have been.

When I first watched Zootopia as a child, I was captivated by its vibrant color palette, inventive character design, sharp humor, and fluid animation. Revisiting the franchise years later with Zootopia 2, I carried high expectations shaped by nostalgia and maturity. Although the work of Jared Bush and Byron Howard not only met those expectations but surpassed them in ways that couldn't satisfy me more watching a movie.

The film continues the journey of Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde, now as detectives, and their dynamic remains one of its best. Their opposite personalities, Judy's boundless optimism against Nick's carelessness (unless it's about her) create a compelling partnership that is perfectly matched.

One of the aspects I admire most is the insane attention to detail. Judy's ears alone, reacting to emotionals as fear, empathy, anger, concentration and reflecting the animators deep understanding of body language. Each character model is rendered with remarkable precision as individual hair strands, eyelashes, claws, and textures all demonstrate a level of art that speaks to genuine passion. The variety of outfits and environments showcases a love, further by thoughtfully matched sound design and finely tuned lighting and color work. The voice cast fits perfectly aligned with their characters, and the humor remains as fun and for all ages as the original film.

The movie succeeds in illustrating that differences between individuals do not necessarily deny their compatibility but rather they can strengthen bonds and inspire growth. The narrative reinforces the importance of fighting for those we care about, a message both beautiful and teaching for generations. I truly hope Disney continues embracing stories with this kind of emotional depth.

The only reason I won't give the film a full 10/10 is that it left me wanting more but personally I would have enjoyed the development of some kind of romantic story, even if unrealistic. After all, animation has always had the freedom to imagine the impossible.

Overall, Zootopia 2 gives me faith in Disney's ability to create meaningful, visually stunning, and timeless movies. I look forward to seeing how they continue to evolve this beloved world.

The pacing was atrocious, as with many modern movies. The beginning was very fast paced, not leaving any room to breath. The middle was better, but nothing to save my opinion on it. The end was still somewhat fast, with an uninteresting and horribly written apology from the main characters that wouldn't stop.

The issue is that this isn't some complex characterization of reptiles and mammals, it's a cut and dry "this side is bad and we kicked them out". Even the first movie didn't have such a simple minded view on predators and prey. Not even bringing that up in the first movie just makes the movie seem extremely prejudiced, like the whole concept just purposely excludes a group of people while everyone knows it.

Character development, while including the quality of writing in the review, was very direct and vocal while still sounding like a millennial writing a relationship. Nick constantly brought up his childhood directly when it wasn't even mentioned or implied. Now once is ok, but when you do this multiple times so the viewer knows why, it's just poor writing. Just comparing the scene of nick talking about his childhood to Judy in the first movie on the tram, and any scene in the second movie other than when Judy's pen broke, should immediately show what i'm talking about.

While i could pick apart the entire movie, that would take a very long time. I've secretly wanted to do the same with the Five night's at Freddy's movie, but realistically there isn't a big enough audience for that amount of work. Anyway's just know that any "its for kids" comment can be immediately disproven by how good the first movie and any other "good" kids movie were.

summary: An unremarkable movie not as good as Zootopia 1
text:
This movie follows a typical Disney formula, but its character development and plot progression don't hold up to scrutiny, leaving me deeply disappointed.

In terms of the characters, Judy wants to prove that she and Nick are the best partners, yet she consistently overlooks her own partner. Nick believes Judy should prioritize her, but he fails to express this clearly. While the overall storyline flows smoothly, it feels rushed, with all characters behaving like NPCs triggering plot points. The conflict between Judy and Nick stems from their differing values, yet when they open up to communicate, they never address this. Shouldn't Judy express gratitude to Nick and apologize for neglecting her partner? Shouldn't Nick apologize to Judy for his nonchalant and cynical attitude? However, the film lacks such reflection and understanding, focusing instead on confessing their psychological traumas to each other. The key issue is that attributing the harm they caused each other entirely to insecurity and anxiety is a way to avoid the problem, not a solution. The entire movie should have built Judy and Nick's characters around discovering, understanding, and resolving their differences. The character development should have culminated in them becoming the best partners precisely because they care about each other and are willing to acknowledge their own flaws and understand each other's concerns, rather than reducing the problem to one being insecure and the other anxious, which does little to foster their growth.

In terms of the plot, it can only be described as formulaic-it doesn't hold up under close scrutiny, as many logical inconsistencies become apparent. For example, why would Gary assume Bobbert would help him? What if it was a trap? And why would Judy, who doesn't know Gary, trust him so readily upon their first meeting? And so on.

In conclusion, this film works as a light and relaxing watch, but if you're here specifically for Judy and Nick, it's best to temper your expectations.

It's hard not to suspect the lengthy buildup contains ideas the writers loved but couldn't bear to cut, or perhaps was simply an excuse for Disney to showcase its dazzling animation capabilities.

The primary storyline is largely sound, except for one segment where the fast development felt solely designed to highlight Judy's individual skill. The real flaws are in the subplots and dropped threads, such as: What was the deal with Mayor Winddancer? Was he truly dealt with? And was the Pig Officer who fired the final shot truly compromised?

Tone & Theme (The Major Flaw) (C-)

This is where the sequel truly falters. The tone is excessively humorous, losing the undercurrent of subdued despair and existential melancholy that permeated the first film. The original's subtle darkness was essential; it was what made Judy's spirit and her optimistic drive to break down stereotypes and combat societal prejudice so valuable. It showcased a small figure fighting against the tide and rebelling against her destiny.

In this film, Judy often feels like she's creating trouble unnecessarily, as many complications could have been avoided. It positions itself as a police story but strips away the essence of police work, portraying its two officer protagonists and the entire ZPD as clueless buffoons largely irrelevant to the plot's core. The sequel devolves into a pure adventure story, losing all thematic depth.

If this script were for a film like The Bad Guys 2, it would be a perfect fit. But for a Zootopia film, I believe it falls short of the mark.

A Final Note on Romance (A+)

While the visuals didn't feel like a noticeable upgrade and occasionally bordered on visual fatigue, the emotional payoff was excellent. Compared to the "space kiss" in The Bad Guys 2, the subtle, mutual need and care between Judy and Nick-only explicitly stated at the very end-is far more exhilarating. I absolutely adore this kind of emotional development. Give me more!

That's it.

summary: Best sequel Disney has ever put out
text:
Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde are back in action after 9 years in a sequel to the blockbuster movie Zootopia from 2016! This time we'll hop on an adventure in which our beloved bunny-fox duo gets dragged onto a conspiracy that has its roots in the foundation of Zootopia around 100 or so years ago. They face challenges as they try to unravel the mysteries of the past and bring justice to those who have been wronged. New jolly-bunch of funny characters are met in the film and there is a lot of physical and verbal humour and clever dialogue that keeps the whole family entertained throughout the film.

The visuals and the animation are spectacularly well made and the cast and music is amazing. The chemistry between the characters is magnificently well written, especially Judy's and Nick's, as is the plot. Pop-culture references fit in successfully and no side character is overused to the point of annoyance. Some characters should have been developed further but otherwise nothing will feel out of place and everything clicks into place. Despite the film not bringing anything new or unique to the table, satisfaction is guaranteed and one may step out of the theater with a heart aflutter full of hopes and dreams.

Honestly speaking, I haven't had this much genuine fun or felt this good in a long time when going in and out of movies. Zootopia 2 is not a perfect movie but it was a sequel worth waiting for. Disney has a bad reputation with its sequels but they definitely cooked with this one. It's a certified banger movie and a modern (to be) classic.

Anyways, go see Zootopia 2 in theaters if you haven't already. It's definitely worth seeing and arguably better than its predecessor. I give it a solid 9/10.
